thread.title: Ashes 2015: No African-born players in England side after Gary Ballance was dropped |
thread.title_full: Ashes 2015: No African-born players in England side after Gary Ballance was dropped | The Advertiser

title: Ashes 2015: No African-born players in England side after Gary Ballance was dropped |
text:
ENGLAND’S African era is about to come to an end.
When the two sides walk out onto the field at Edgbaston for the start of the third Ashes Test, it will be the first time in more than a decade that England has fielded a Test team that doesn’t feature a player born in Africa.
The axing of Zimbabwe-born Gary Ballance means the 139-Test reign of African influence is now over.
That dates back to the 2004 Test debut of Andrew Strauss, who moved from South Africa to England at the age of six and went on to be one of that country’s best batsmen and captains.
BROADSIDE: HOW AN AUSSIE FAN SNAPPED THIS ANGRY PHOTO
PRINGLE: UNWANTED RECORD ON CARDS FOR ENGLAND
Andrew Strauss (L) and Kevin Pietersen actually have a fair bit in common. Source: Getty Images
He was followed by a gentleman by the name of Kevin Pietersen, who moved to the UK at a far later age — 19 — to pursue his dream of playing Test cricket, something he achieved during the 2005 Ashes series.
The African legion rose with the addition of Matt Prior and Jonathan Trott, meaning at one stage four of England’s top seven batsmen were originally from South Africa.
Strauss’s departure didn’t prevent other African-born players from following in his footsteps, with Nick Compton — the South African-born grandson of England legend Denis Compton — debuting in 2012 before Ballance appeared for the Three Lions at the end of the 2013-14 Ashes series.
The poor form of Gary Ballance brought England’s African era to an end. Source: AFP
However, Jonny Bairstow’s inclusion at the expense of Ballance hasn’t completely ended the era of people from overseas playing Test cricket for England. Star all-rounder Ben Stokes lived in New Zealand until the age of 12, although a decade of living in the north of England has ensured he sounds more Newcastle than New Plymouth.
This is all before taking a look at England’s limited-overs sides. The one-day team is captained by Irishman Eoin Morgan, and in recent years has featured the likes of South African-born players Jade Dernbach, Jason Roy and Michael Lumb.
Meanwhile fringe national team member Chris Jordan grew up in Barbados and once shared a classroom with music superstar Rihanna.
Originally published as England’s African era comes to an end
